concepts.description: The positive integer coefficient m such that a fiber F appears as mF in a divisorial decomposition of the total space.

concepts.label: ramification locus
concepts.description: The locus where a map fails to be étale, where fibers acquire multiplicity or singularities.

concepts.label: discrepancy
concepts.description: A numerical invariant a(E,X) measuring the singularity type of a variety; positive discrepancy characterizes terminal singularities.

concepts.label: classification theorem
concepts.description: A theorem enumerating or characterizing geometric objects up to isomorphism or equivalence within a constrained family.

concepts.label: Mori fibration
concepts.description: A fibration of a Fano variety with relative Picard number one, fundamental in the minimal model program.

concepts.label: quasi-effective threshold
concepts.description: The supremum of coefficients in the anticanonical divisor decomposition for which the variety remains log del Pezzo.

concepts.label: adjunction threshold
concepts.description: The critical value in adjunction-type singularity analysis determining when the canonical divisor becomes effective along the fibration.

concepts.label: affine 3-space
concepts.description: Three-dimensional affine space over an algebraically closed field, the basic open variety to be compactified.

concepts.label: factorial threefold
concepts.description: A three-dimensional normal variety with unique factorization of Weil divisors into irreducible divisors.

concepts.label: closed fiber
concepts.description: The scheme-theoretic fiber of a morphism over a closed point; typically a special fiber of a fibration.

concepts.label: prime divisor
concepts.description: An irreducible divisor (codimension-1 subvariety) on an algebraic variety.

concepts.label: horizontal divisor
concepts.description: A divisor on the total space of a fibration that is not contained in any fiber (dominant over the base).

concepts.label: integral curves
concepts.description: Irreducible one-dimensional subvarieties (curves) on an algebraic variety.

concepts.label: almost regular bundle
concepts.description: A principal bundle on a del Pezzo surface satisfying specific regularity properties, characterized by unique existence up to isomorphism on Gorenstein del Pezzo surfaces.

concepts.label: Gorenstein del Pezzo surface
concepts.description: A del Pezzo surface with at most canonical singularities; the natural setting for almost regular bundle classification.

concepts.label: bundle isomorphism
concepts.description: Equivalence relation identifying two principal bundles that are equivalent as geometric objects; defines equivalence classes.

concepts.label: Friedman-Morgan theory
concepts.description: The foundational classification result for regular bundles on del Pezzo surfaces establishing uniqueness properties.

concepts.label: non-Gorenstein singularities
concepts.description: Singularities where the dualizing sheaf is not invertible; quotient singularities that fail the Gorenstein condition.

concepts.label: K-condition
concepts.description: A technical divisibility or integrality condition on singularities that constrains the structure of del Pezzo fibrations.

concepts.label: rationality
concepts.description: Property that a variety is birational to projective space; equivalently, has a dominant rational map from P^n.

concepts.label: rationally connected variety
concepts.description: A variety through any two general points of which passes a rational curve; admits a dominant rational map from P^1.

concepts.label: Cremona group
concepts.description: Group of birational automorphisms of projective space P^n; embeddings of finite quotients encode geometric rigidity.

concepts.label: birational embedding
concepts.description: A birational morphism or inclusion of one variety into another, preserving rational functions.

concepts.label: smooth fibration
concepts.description: A fibration whose total space and all fibers are smooth varieties.

concepts.label: singular model
concepts.description: A geometric model or variety allowing singularities; here, del Pezzo fibrations with non-Gorenstein terminal singularities.

concepts.label: semiorthogonal decomposition
concepts.description: Decomposition of a triangulated category into a sequence of orthogonal subcategories with specified generation properties.

concepts.label: Gorenstein singularity
concepts.description: A singularity with canonical divisor locally isomorphic to a regular divisor; characterized by dualizing sheaf properties.

concepts.label: relative moduli space
concepts.description: A moduli space parametrizing objects (e.g., sheaves or divisors) on fibers of a fibration, varying smoothly over the base.

concepts.label: Homological Projective Duality
concepts.description: A duality between derived categories of varieties related through linear projections, extending classical projective duality to derived settings.

concepts.label: Grassmannian bundle
concepts.description: A bundle whose fibers are Grassmannians (spaces of linear subspaces), providing a geometric structure for constructing varieties via linear sections.

concepts.label: linear section
concepts.description: A closed subvariety obtained as the intersection of a variety with a linear subspace of the ambient projective space.

concepts.label: sextic del Pezzo fibration
concepts.description: A fibration whose fibers are degree-6 del Pezzo surfaces; studied via moduli space methods analogous to quintic case.

concepts.label: finite flat morphism
concepts.description: A proper morphism of finite type with finite fibers that is flat, preserving fiber-wise degree information.

concepts.label: triangulated category
concepts.description: An additive category equipped with a shift functor and a class of distinguished triangles satisfying axioms; the framework for derived categories.

concepts.label: degree 4 del Pezzo
concepts.description: A del Pezzo surface of degree 4, obtained as a smooth complete intersection of two quadrics in ℙ³ or via other constructions.

concepts.label: characteristic p geometry
concepts.description: Study of algebraic varieties and moduli over fields of positive characteristic p, as opposed to characteristic 0.

concepts.label: existence theorem
concepts.description: A proof establishing existence of objects (here, standard models) satisfying specified geometric or algebro-geometric properties.

concepts.label: smooth curve
concepts.description: A one-dimensional projective or quasi-projective variety without singularities.

concepts.label: nonsingular variety
concepts.description: A variety where every point has a smooth local model; no singularities.

concepts.label: relative linear section
concepts.description: A subvariety obtained by intersection with hyperplane bundles in a fibered family, generalizing linear sections to families.

concepts.label: embedding theorem
concepts.description: A result asserting that a geometric object can be realized as a linear section of a higher-dimensional variety.

concepts.label: fiber classification
concepts.description: Enumeration and characterization of all possible fiber types in a family of varieties up to birational equivalence.

concepts.label: invariant divisor
concepts.description: A divisor fixed pointwise or setwise by a group action, often used to study quotient varieties.

concepts.label: torsion index
concepts.description: An invariant measuring the order of torsion elements in the Picard group or relative Picard group of an algebraic variety.

concepts.label: relatively torsion line bundle
concepts.description: A line bundle on a fibered variety whose restriction to the generic fiber is a torsion element in the Picard group.

concepts.label: inseparable section
concepts.description: A morphism from the base curve to the total space that is purely inseparable in characteristic p, arising from the Frobenius endomorphism.

concepts.label: log del Pezzo surface
concepts.description: A log del Pezzo pair (X,B) where X is a normal surface and B is a boundary divisor such that -(K_X+B) is ample.

concepts.label: imperfect field
concepts.description: A field that is not perfect; in positive characteristic, a field where the Frobenius endomorphism is not surjective on absolute elements.

concepts.label: Frobenius endomorphism
concepts.description: The p-th power map x ↦ x^p acting on a variety in characteristic p, fundamental to studying inseparability.

concepts.label: bound on degree
concepts.description: An explicit upper bound on the degree of a section or morphism in terms of invariants of the base and fibers.

edges.evidence: One-form symmetries are a special case of higher-form symmetries; the abstract mentions 'higher-form symmetries, which are commonplace' and studies 'center one-form symmetries' as instance thereof.
Center one-form symmetries are broken by BPS states in Calabi-Yau compactifications (abstract: 'center one-form symmetries broken by BPS states').

Global symmetries including higher-form symmetries must be broken in quantum gravity: 'It is widely believed that global symmetries must be broken in Quantum Gravity. This includes higher-form symmetries.'
Center one-form symmetries arise in CY compactifications of type IIA/M-theory as studied in this work (abstract scope).
Parameters quantifying symmetry breaking are evaluated for large and small values of moduli, indicating moduli-dependence of breaking extent.
Type IIA string theory is compactified on Calabi-Yau threefolds as stated in abstract.
M-theory compactifications on CY3 are studied alongside type IIA in this work (abstract).
Higher-form symmetries are commonplace in supergravity coupled to vector multiplets (abstract).
Supergravity couples to vector multiplets carrying higher-form symmetries in CY compactifications.
Symmetry breaking criterion is applied to effective field theories of gravity (abstract).
Scales of significant symmetry breaking are compared with other relevant physical scales to assess hierarchy (abstract).
CY compactifications yield moduli spaces controlling effective theory parameters and geometry.
The procedure constructs log CY compactifications of weak Landau-Ginzburg models, providing a geometric completion of the LG framework.
The construction is applied for del Pezzo surfaces and coverings of projective spaces, which are special cases of Fano varieties.
For coverings of degree greater than 2, the log CY compactification is singular; singularities appear over infinity and at finite points.
The degree of the covering (d > 2) directly influences whether smooth projective log CY compactifications exist or singularities necessarily arise.
The dimension of the anticanonical system equals the number of components in the fiber over infinity and of finite fibers (main conjecture proven).
Fano varieties are fundamentally defined by having ample anticanonical divisor, making the anticanonical system a central structural invariant.
Index one covers form a distinguished subfamily of coverings of projective space, providing a normalization condition on the anticanonical index.
Log CY compactifications allow controlled singularities, generalizing the classical requirement that compactifications be smooth.
Landau-Ginzburg models and their geometric completions via log CY structures participate in mirror symmetry dualities.
LG models are studied through derived categories and homological mirror symmetry, connecting to D-brane physics.
Complete Calabi-Yau metrics are Ricci-flat with respect to exact Kähler forms satisfying ∂∂̄ φ = 0.
The construction yields Calabi-Yau metrics of maximal volume growth on smoothings.
The tangent cone at infinity is the limiting cone geometry obtained from the Calabi-Yau metric.
QAC metrics exhibit transition behavior between different Calabi-Yau cones at infinity.
Isolated conical singularities are modelled on a Calabi-Yau cone distinct from the tangent cone at infinity.
Weighted blow-up for manifolds with corners provides a compactification describing geometry at infinity.
Deriving mapping properties of the Laplacian on weighted Hölder spaces is a key analytical step in metric construction.
Analysis of the Laplacian is performed on suitable weighted Hölder spaces.
Metrics are constructed on smoothings of Cartesian products of Calabi-Yau cones.
The constructed examples are complete Calabi-Yau metrics on smoothed cone products.
The tangent cone at infinity does not uniquely specify a complete Calabi-Yau metric with exact Kähler form, as demonstrated by examples with different conical singularities.
Cartesian products are formed from Calabi-Yau cones with smooth cross-sections.
QAC methods produce singular Calabi-Yau metrics with isolated conical singularities modelled on distinct cones.
crystals with the properties of crystalline cohomology of ordinary Calabi-Yau threefolds in characteristic p>0
ordinary Calabi-Yau threefolds in characteristic p>0 are Calabi-Yau threefolds studied via crystalline methods
boundary point of the moduli space with maximal unipotent local monodromy
exhibit a remarkable similarity with the well known structure...near a boundary point of the moduli space with maximal unipotent local monodromy
canonical coordinates and an analogue of the prepotential of the Yukawa coupling; in these coordinates prepotential has systematic form
prepotential encodes Yukawa couplings; prepotential of the Yukawa coupling
p-adic analogues of the integrality properties for the canonical coordinates and the prepotential
integrality properties...of the prepotential...have been observed in the examples of Mirror Symmetry
show p-adic analogues of the integrality properties...for ordinary Calabi-Yau threefolds
p-adic analogues of the integrality properties for the canonical coordinates and prepotential
integrality properties...have been observed in the examples of Mirror Symmetry
Calabi-Yau threefolds have cohomology structure with Hodge numbers and holonomy constraints
Yukawa couplings are triple intersection products within CY cohomology
canonical coordinates on moduli space near MUM point
CY threefolds defined by SU(3) holonomy group, vanishing first Chern class.
Hodge numbers h^{1,1} and h^{2,1} are central topological invariants classifying CY3 geometry.
D₆ dihedral symmetry acts on 20 complex-structure moduli, reducing them to 5 D₆-invariant combinations.
